animalOfTheDay.name: umbrellabird
facts: Umbrellabirds get their name from the distinctive umbrella-like crest on the male's head.
They have one of the deepest voices in the bird world, producing loud, booming calls.
They are found only in the rainforests of Central and South America.
Males gather in groups called leks to perform courtship displays for females.

calendar.name: toad
facts: Toads have dry, warty skin, while frogs have smooth, moist skin.
They secrete toxins from their skin to deter predators, which can be harmful if ingested.
Toads are more terrestrial than frogs and are often found far from water.
Some toads, like the cane toad, have become invasive species in certain regions.

calendar.name: topi
facts: They have specialized scent glands that help them mark their territory.
They have a unique 'pronking' behavior where they leap stiff-legged when alarmed.
Topis are fast antelopes that can reach speeds of up to 50 mph.
Male topis defend small territories where females come to mate.

calendar.name: trout
facts: Trout have excellent vision and can see in color.
They can detect vibrations in the water through their lateral line system.
Some trout species migrate between freshwater and saltwater during their life cycle.
They are indicators of clean water and are sensitive to pollution.

calendar.name: sloth
facts: Sloths are the slowest mammals on Earth, moving at a top speed of about 0.24 km/h.
They spend most of their lives hanging upside down in trees, even sleeping and giving birth in this position.
Sloths have a symbiotic relationship with algae, which grows on their fur and provides camouflage.
They only come down from the trees about once a week to defecate.

calendar.name: turkey
facts: Wild turkeys can fly short distances at speeds of up to 55 mph.
They have excellent vision and can see in color, with a nearly 360-degree field of view.
Male turkeys, called toms, puff up their feathers and fan their tails to attract females.
Benjamin Franklin once proposed the turkey as the national bird of the United States.

calendar.name: turtle
facts: Turtles have been around for over 200 million years, outliving the dinosaurs.
They can breathe through their butts (cloacal respiration) when hibernating underwater.
The gender of many turtle species is determined by the temperature of the nest.
Some turtles, like the leatherback, can dive to depths of over 4,000 feet.

calendar.name: umbrellabird
facts: They are found only in the rainforests of Central and South America.
Males gather in groups called leks to perform courtship displays for females.
Umbrellabirds get their name from the distinctive umbrella-like crest on the male's head.
They have one of the deepest voices in the bird world, producing loud, booming calls.

randomAnimals.name: robin
facts: They are one of the first birds to sing at dawn, earning them the nickname 'the early bird.'
Robins sing year-round, with males using song to establish territory and attract mates.
They are territorial and will aggressively defend their feeding areas in winter.
Robins are known for their red breasts, which are brighter in males during breeding season.

randomAnimals.name: mule
facts: Mules are hybrids, the offspring of a male donkey and a female horse.
Mules are known for their strength, endurance, and sure-footedness.
They are sterile, with almost all mules unable to reproduce.
They have longer ears than horses and a more stubborn reputation.

randomAnimals.name: cockatoo
facts: They're incredibly intelligent and can learn to solve complex puzzles.
Cockatoos can live over 100 years, making them lifelong companions.
Cockatoos are very social and can become depressed without interaction.
Their powerful beaks can crack the hardest nuts and seeds.
